section.title: Timelines
section.p: The key to financial mathematics is understanding the special role time plays in finance. Money today is worth more than money later due to deferred compensation as well as a variety of risks, such as inflation and non-payment.

A cash flow is a sequence of payments, such as deposits or withdrawals in an account. An entry in a cash flow is positive if it comes into the pot and negative if it leaves the pot - this depends greatly on context! Cash flows can be finite or infinite.

The main tool used to understand cash flows is a timeline, which is basically an axis with tick-marks measuring time in units that are appropriate for the problem. task.p: $10,000 is deposited into an account today. After 5 years, $5,000 is withdrawn.
An heir receives $5,000 at the end of every year for the next 5 years.
$1,000 is deposited at the end of every year for the next 2 years, and X is withdrawn immediately after the second deposit, and again one year after.

Joe deposits 10 today and 30 in five years. Tina will make the same two deposits, but the 10 will be deposited n years from today and the 30 will be deposited 2n years from today. (Consider making two separate timelines).

section.p: The future value at time t of an amount deposited at time 0 is A(t) = A(0)(1+\iota)^t In this equation, A(0) is the amount deposited and \iota is the interest rate.
If the amount was not deposited at time 0, but instead at time t_1, then the value at time t_2 is A(t_2) = A(t_1)(1+\iota)^{t_2-t_1}

introduction.p: Suppose 1000 was deposited at the end of Year 2, 2000 was deposited at the end of Year 4, and a withdrawal of X is made at the end of Year 9. The balance immediately after the withdrawal is 1200. The account carries an annual interest rate of \iota = 3\%.

section.p: The present value is the amount that would have to be deposited now in order to generate the cash flows indicated. Unless otherwise specified, the present value is at time 0, and it can be calculated by solving the future value equation for A(0).

section.p: The interest added to an account at time t is \iota A(t-1), where A(t-1) is the balance at time t-1 and \iota is the interest rate.
